Support effect on the catalytic activity and selectivity of SILP catalysts in isobutene trimerization Csaba Fehér a Eszter Kriván b József Kovács c Jenő Hancsók b Rita Skoda-Földes a ⁎ a University of Pannonia, Institute of Chemistry, Department of Organic Chemistry, H-8201 Veszprém, P.O. Box 158, Hungary b University of Pannonia, Department of MOL Hydrocarbon and Coal Processing, H-8201 Veszprém, P.O. Box 158, Hungary c University of Pannonia, Institute of Environmental Engineering, H-8201 Veszprém, P.O.Box 158, Hungary ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +36 88 624719; fax: +36 88 624469. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Good selectivity in trimerization of isobutene was achieved. ► Silica supported Brønsted acidic ionic liquids were used as catalysts. ► Close relationship exists between pore structure and catalytic activity of SILP material. Oligomerization of isobutene has been carried out using silica supported Brønsted acidic ionic liquid catalysts. Silica supports with different particle size and textural properties have been used to prepare the catalysts. A close relationship between these properties and catalytic activity of the SILP material was observed. Silica supports with mesoporous structure could be converted to very active catalysts. On the other hand, the use of microporous supports resulted in the formation of catalysts with excellent C12 selectivity. Keywords Oligomerization Brønsted acidic ionic liquid Silica support Pore structure 1 Introduction The C4 stream, including isobutene, is an important raw material in the petroleum and petrochemical industry. By the hydrogenation of dimerization products of low molecular weight olefins, an excellent gasoline blend stock with high octane number and low volatility can be produced. A further advantage of these blending components is the complete absence of sulphur and aromatic compounds [1]. At the same time, trimerization and following hydrogenation of light olefins has also attracted considerable attention recently, as a method for the production of blending components for jet fuel [2]. Trimerization of isobutene can be carried out using acid resins [3,4], WO x /ZrO2 [5], sulfated titania [6] or special zeolites [7–10]. Beside the solid acid catalysts, ionic liquids with Lewis acidic [11,12] or Brønsted acidic [13] character were shown to catalyze isobutene oligomerization efficiently. In most cases, selective dimerization was observed, but selectivity could be influenced slightly by the N-alkyl chain length of the imidazolium-type ionic liquid catalyst. The use of an ionic liquid with imidazolium cations with longer side chains led to higher selectivity for trimeric products [13]. Recently, we have shown that silica supported 1-(4-sulfobutyl)-3-alkylimidazolium ionic liquids are easy-to-handle and reusable catalysts for isobutene oligomerization [14]. It was shown that various factors, such as pretreatment of the solid support, the choice of cation and anion, as well as the reaction time and temperature, affected considerably the outcome of the reaction. Although the SILP technique (supported ionic liquid phase) has been used for the heterogenization of a great variety of homogeneous catalysts lately, there is little information about the effect of the structure of the supports. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and investigation of morphological properties and oligomerization activity of catalysts obtained by the adsorption of 1-(4-sulfobutyl)-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate on different silica supports. 2 Experimental 1-(4-Sulfobutyl)-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate was synthesized as described before [14]. Silica supports were purchased from Merck (particle size 0.040–0.063mm (S-1) and FLUKA (particle size: 0.2–0.5mm (S-2), 1–3mm (S-3) and 3–6mm (S-4). 2.1 Preparation of supported ionic liquids (SILP-1–SILP-7) The methods for preparation of supported ionic liquids are summarized in Table 1 . The amount of adsorbed ionic liquid was determined by measuring the weight increase after heating the material to constant weight at 150°C in vacuo. Method A Silica gel was pre-treated by heating for 5h at 250°C. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature in a desiccator and was stored under argon. A mixture of silica gel (10g), the ionic liquid (10mmol) and 25ml MeOH was stirred at room temperature for 24h. MeOH was removed in vacuo and the catalyst was dried at 60°C in vacuo for 1h to produce the supported ionic liquid. Method B Silica gel was pre-treated by heating for 5h at 250°C. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature in a desiccator and was stored under argon. A mixture of silica gel (20g) and the ionic liquid (10mmol) was refluxed in 50ml MeOH for 5h. MeOH was removed in vacuo and the catalyst was dried at 60°C in vacuo for 1h to produce the supported ionic liquid. Method C Silica gel was pre-treated by heating for 5h at 250°C. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature in a desiccator and was stored under argon. A mixture of silica gel (20g) and the ionic liquid (10mmol) was refluxed in 50ml MeOH for 5h. MeOH was removed in vacuo and the catalyst was dried at 150°C in vacuo for 5h to produce the supported ionic liquid. Method D Silica gel was pre-treated by heating for 5h at 250°C. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature in a desiccator and was stored under argon. A mixture of silica gel (20g) and the ionic liquid (10mmol) was refluxed in 50ml MeOH for 5h. MeOH was removed in vacuo. Then 50ml oligomer product mixture was added and the mixture was heated at 150°C for 5h. The catalyst was filtered, washed with pentane (3× 20ml) and dried at 150°C in vacuo for 5h to produce the supported ionic liquid. Method E Silica gel was pre-treated by heating for 5h at 250°C. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature in a desiccator and was stored under argon. A mixture of silica gel (20g) and the ionic liquid (10mmol) was refluxed in 50ml MeOH for 5h. MeOH was removed in vacuo. Then 50ml toluene was added and the mixture was refluxed for 5h. The catalyst was filtered, washed with pentane (3× 20ml) and dried at 150°C in vacuo for 5h to produce the supported ionic liquid. 2.2 Oligomerization of isobutene The reactions were carried out in an autoclave under argon. The autoclave was cooled to −15°C and isobutene (5ml, 57.5mmol) was charged into the reactor, which contained the catalyst (1g (SILP-1, SILP-2) or 2g (SILP-3–SILP-7)). The autoclave was pressurized with argon (22bar, room temperature). In a typical reaction the mixture was stirred at 100°C for 5h. The autoclave was cooled to −15°C, the organic phase was separated and analyzed by gas chromatography. The SILP catalysts were washed with pentane (3× 5ml), dried in vacuo and reused. 2.3 Analysis of product mixtures The conversion and selectivity of the reactions were determined by analyzing the composition of the reaction mixtures with a GC equipped with a FID detector and a 30m HP-1 column. The assignment of the chromatographic peaks was carried out by GC–MS measurements (HP-5890A GC, HP 5971A MSD). The mass spectra were compared to literature data [4]. 2.4 Analysis of the supported catalysts The specific surface area and pore size distribution in the micropore (0–2nm), mesopore (2–50nm), and the macropore (50–300nm) diameter ranges were determined by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms measured with a Micromeritics ASAP 2000-type instrument on samples previously out gassed overnight in vacuum at the temperature of 150°C. The surface areas of the samples (S BET) were determined by the BET method from the corresponding nitrogen adsorption isotherm. The meso and macropore (2–300nm in diameter) volume values were calculated from the nitrogen desorption isotherms using the BJH (Barret–Joyner–Halenda) theory. Acidity of the catalysts fresh and reused were determined by means of NH3 pulse chemisorption at a steady temperature (30°C) with the aid of a PulseChemisorb type 2705 instrument produced by Micromeritics Instrument Corp. The samples (200mg) were heated for 4h at 250°C under an ultrapure He (Messer GmbH >99.9995%) gas flow, then cooled to 30°C overnight and the controlled amount of ammonia gas (Messer GmbH >99.98%) was injected. The gas interacts with each active site until all sites have chemisorbed. Once the active sites have completely filled, the discretely injected ammonia gas volume elutes from the sample tube unchanged. The amount of chemisorbed NH3 is the difference between the total amount of the injected gas and the amount of the gas eluted from the sample. The quantity (μmol/g catalyst sample) of each pulse of chemisorbed gas was determined by the volume of syringe injections. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic experiments Previously, we reported on the oligomerization of isobutene in the presence of supported ionic liquid catalysts prepared by the adsorption of ionic liquids on S-1. In quest of a suitable catalyst to scale up the process, silica supports of larger particle size (S-2–S-4) were impregnated with 1-(4-sulfobutyl)-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate. The efficiency of the new catalysts was tested in the oligomerization of isobutene. SILP-1 [14] and SILP-2 catalysts, obtained by impregnation of silica supports with 0.040–0.063mm and 0.2–0.5mm particle size, respectively, showed similar performance. They were used several times without loss of activity (Fig. 1 ). Total conversion was obtained in each case. The main products were the C12 isomers obtained with 49–59% and 51–58% selectivity with SILP-1 and SILP-2, respectively. Slightly higher activity of SILP-2 can be demonstrated by experiments carried out at lower temperatures (Fig. 2 ) (at 60°C TOF(SILP-1)=9.3h−1, TOF(SILP-2)=10.9h−1). When shorter reaction times were used, SILP-2 showed better selectivity for trimers (57–60%, Fig. 3 ) than SILP-1 (44–46%). Then, silica gel with considerably larger particle size (S-4) was chosen as the support. Preparation of a supported catalyst was attempted by Method A. However, due to stirring, the support granules were broken and a catalyst with a considerable smaller particle size was obtained. To avoid this, impregnation was carried out by refluxing the mixture to guarantee sufficient interaction of the components. In both cases, after removal of the solvent, the presence of a residue of non-adsorbed ionic liquid could be observed instead of the formation of a solid material. In the next experiment, the ratio of silica gel/ionic liquid was increased (Method B) and thus a suitable solid catalyst (SILP-3) was formed. To obtain comparable results in the oligomerization experiments, a twofold amount of the catalyst (2g instead of 1g) was used in order to keep the isobutene/ionic liquid ratio constant. The catalyst was used in eight consecutive runs. Excellent C12 selectivity (65–70%) was observed in Runs 2–8. At the same time, in contrast to the oligomerization experiments carried out with SILP-1 or SILP-2, a change in both the conversion and selectivity of the reaction was observed in the first runs (Fig. 4 ). It was assumed that this phenomenon might be explained either by the degradation of catalyst particles due to stirring, or to the presence of residual solvent (MeOH) during the first experiment. Accordingly, SILP-4 catalyst was prepared by Method C to remove any traces of solvent, and oligomerization experiments were carried out without stirring. In the presence of SILP-4, a higher catalytic activity was achieved in the first run (99% conversion compared to 95% with SILP-3), and a smaller difference between the selectivities of the first and second run was observed (Fig. 5 ). At the same time, the average conversion was lower (97–100%) and although good C12 selectivity (65–70%) was obtained, the results were less reproducible probably because of the lack of stirring. In order to avoid the change of selectivity between the first two runs, the catalyst was pretreated by refluxing it in a product mixture (SILP-5). In this case, although there was no tendency in the change of the results of the first oligomerization experiments, conversions were lower than before (88–98%) and poor selectivity for C12 (49–64%) was achieved (Fig. 6 ). As it is usual [2], dimer selectivity increased with decreasing isobutene conversion: oligomerization of isobutene is a consecutive reaction, so lower conversion leads to higher dimer selectivity. It was assumed that the precipitation of some high-boiling point oligomers on the catalyst might decrease catalytic activity. So another solvent, toluene, was chosen for the pretreatment of the catalyst (SILP-6, Method E). Toluene has sufficiently high boiling point, does not dissolve the ionic liquid and inert in the oligomerization reaction. SILP-6 showed a stable performance and excellent C12 selectivity (67–70%, Fig. 7 ). At the same time, experiments carried out at lower temperature (Fig. 8 ) or with shorter reaction time (Fig. 9 ) showed that SILP-6 was a less active catalyst than SILP-1 or SILP-2 (at 60°C TOF(SILP-6)=7.4h−1). Based on the previous results, 1-(4-sulfobutyl)-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate was adsorbed on S-3 by Method E. A solid catalyst (SILP-7) was obtained by adsorbing 10mmol ionic liquid on 20g of S-3. (It should be mentioned, however, that, similarly to silica gel S-4, the presence of non-adsorbed ionic liquid was observed when using a 10mmol ionic liquid/10g S-3 ratio.) In the oligomerization of isobutene, the performance of SILP-7 (Fig. 10 ) fall behind that of SILP-6. In spite of the pretreatment of the catalyst in toluene, a considerable change in the conversion and selectivity was observed in the first three runs. Also, conversion remained around 90% even after the stabilization of the catalyst. Accordingly, C12 selectivity was poorer (46–63%) than in the presence of SILP-6. The smaller activity of SILP-7 is well demonstrated by the experiments carried out with the stabilized catalyst at lower temperature (Fig. 11 ) or with shorter reaction time (Fig. 12 ). At 60°C, only 58% conversion was achieved compared to 81% obtained with SILP-1. Similarly, at 100°C, only 41% conversion was observed after 1h, while under similar conditions, isobutene was totally converted to the products in the presence of SILP-1. 3.2 Textural properties of SILP materials The values of the specific surface area (S BET) and pore volumes of supports and SILP catalysts (Table 2 ) were determined from the experimental data of their nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms. Assuming that the pores have cylindrical shape, from the values of incremental pore volumes and the average pore diameter, the cumulative surface area (S BJH) can be estimated on the basis of BJH phenomena. S-3 and S-4 have substantially higher BET surface area than S-1 or S-2. There is also a great difference in pore size distribution of the supports. S-1 and S-2 have mesopores, mainly in the 2–10nm region (Fig. 13 ) and have no measurable micropore surface area (Table 2). At the same time, S-3 and S-4 have a considerable amount of micropores that greatly contribute to their BET surface (Table 2), but the total volume of their mesopores is low. As it is expected, there is a loss of BET surface in each case when the support is impregnated with ionic liquid (Table 2). The difference between the BET surface of support and SILP catalyst is greater in the case of supports with micropores. SILP-4 and SILP-6 (obtained from S-4 in refluxing methanol and toluene, respectively) retained some of their micropores but the SILP catalyst pretreated in an olefin mixture (SILP-5) had no measurable micropore surface area. A similar loss of micropores was observed in case of SILP-7. These observations are in accordance with those of Rodriguez, who found that in microporous and mesoporous materials, ionic liquids fill the micropores first [15]. Also, pretreatment at higher temperature led to a further decrease in the BET surface of the SILP catalysts (compare SILP-4 to SILP-5 and SILP-6). Comparing the S BET and S BJH values, it can be assumed that supports S-1 and S-2 have pear shaped pores that retain their shape during the catalyst preparation process, although the total pore volume values decreases because of the active ionic liquid film on the wall of the pores. On the other hand, the microporous S-3 and S-4 supports contain narrow shaped pores that become almost totally filled with ionic liquid film during the catalyst preparation (Figs. 13 and 14 .) In case of SILP-4–SILP-7, the diffusion of isobutene to the micropores is blocked by the ionic liquid that fills the pore, so the contact surface between the ionic liquid phase and the organic phase is lower than that of SILP catalysts with mesopores (SILP-1, SILP-2). The lower contact surface result in lower catalytic activity. At the same time, the formation of a stable film is a prerequisite for an unvarying selectivity of the catalyst, so a high temperature pretreatment is necessary to obtain a suitable catalyst from microporous materials. The acid capacity of SILP-1 and SILP-2 (Table 2) is higher than that of the other SILP materials, in accordance with the different amounts of adsorbed ionic liquid. At the same time, there is only a small difference between the acidity of the catalysts obtained by different methods from S-4. It should be mentioned that some drop of acid capacity of the SILP materials was observed after the catalytic reactions (to 0.67mmol NH3 g−1 (SILP-2, after 8 runs), 0.30mmolNH3 g−1 (SILP-4, after 12 runs) and to 0.31mmolNH3 g−1 (SILP-6, after 12 runs). 4 Conclusions Both mesoporous and microporous materials are suitable for the preparation of SILP catalysts with acidic ionic liquids. The catalysts were proved to be stable and they retained catalytic activity in several experiments. A close relationship between catalytic activity and catalyst morphology was observed. Silica with mesoporous structure was able to adsorb a higher amount of the ionic liquid and produced SILP materials with higher catalytic activity at identical catalyst loadings. At the same time, using a proper pretreatment, an active and stable catalyst with excellent C12 selectivity (SILP-6) can be obtained from microporous silica S-4. coredata.dc:description: Oligomerization of isobutene has been carried out using silica supported Brønsted acidic ionic liquid catalysts. Silica supports with different particle size and textural properties have been used to prepare the catalysts. A close relationship between these properties and catalytic activity of the SILP material was observed. Silica supports with mesoporous structure could be converted to very active catalysts. On the other hand, the use of microporous supports resulted in the formation of catalysts with excellent C12 selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Support effect on the catalytic activity and selectivity of SILP catalysts in isobutene trimerization
